Congress, by a two-thirds vote of both the Senate and the House of Representatives, may propose an amendment to the Constitution, or two-thirds of state legislatures can ask Congress to call such a convention. If such a proposed amendment is ratified by the legislatures or conventions in three-fourths of the states as Congress decides the ratification should occur, it becomes part of the Constitution.

Any debts or agreements that predated the adoption of this Constitution into law by the United States will continue to be valid under the Constitution as they had been under the old government. The Constitution together with the laws of the United States made in pursuance thereof and all treaties made is the Supreme law of the land. It means that all states must follow it even though the law or constitution of a state says something to the contrary. All Senators, Representatives, members of the state legislatures, and all executive and judicial officers of the United States and of the several states, shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation, to support this Constitution. However, no one can be required to pass a religious test in order to hold a government job or position of trust in the United States.

All that needed to occur for the Constitution to take effect was for conventions in nine states to ratify-that is, to approve-it. In that event, the Constitution would apply to those nine accepting states.

Congress cannot make any laws that create an official religion or stop people from practicing their religion freely. It also cannot make laws that limit freedom of speech, freedom of the press, the right of people to gather peacefully, or the right to ask the government to fix problems or address complaints.
Since a well-organized militia is important for the security of a free country, people have the right to own and carry weapons, and this right cannot be taken away.
Soldiers cannot be housed in someone’s home without the homeowner’s permission. Even during war, this can only happen in a way that follows the law.

People have the right to security in their bodies, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures; which can not be violated without probable cause of valid reasons. No warrant of search and seizure shall issue without legitimate basis, and particularly describing the place to be searched and the persons or things to be seized.

No one can be put on trial for a serious crime unless a Grand Jury formally charges them, except for cases involving the military during war or public emergencies. A person cannot be tried twice for the same crime (double jeopardy), nor can they be forced to testify against themselves. No one can be punished or lose their life, freedom, or property without going through the proper legal process. Further, the taking of private property by the government for public use must be by just compensation to the owner.

In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury of the State and district wherein the crime shall have been committed, which district shall have been previously ascertained by law. The accused has the right to be informed of the nature of the charges brought against them; to confront witnesses brought against them; to obtain witnesses in favor; and to have the Assistance of Counsel for his defense.

In lawsuits at common law, where the value in controversy exceeds twenty dollars, the right of trial by jury shall be preserved, and no fact tried by a jury, shall be otherwise re-examined in any Court of the United States, than according to the rules of the common law.
Bail and fines cannot be excessively high, and punishments must not be cruel or unusual.
Listing specific rights in the Constitution does not mean that people don't have other rights that are not mentioned.
Any powers that the Constitution does not give to the federal government or ban from the states belong to the states or the people.
The federal courts cannot hear lawsuits brought by citizens of one state against another state or by people from foreign countries against a state.

The electors from each state meet and vote for President and Vice-President. One of these persons must be an inhabitant of another state than themselves. They vote separately for President and Vice-President and forward the votes, along with lists showing the number of votes each candidate received, to the President of the Senate. The votes are to be opened and counted by the President of the Senate, in the presence of the Senate and House of Representatives. A candidate must receive the majority of the votes of the electors to become President. If no one receives a majority, then the House of Representatives, with a quorum of two-thirds of the states being present, and a majority of all the states being necessary to make a choice, shall select the President from the three highest candidates. If the House does not select a President on or before March 4, the Vice-President acts as President until such time as one is selected. For a person to be elected Vice-President, he or she has to have a majority of the votes of the electors. If no one gets this majority, the Senate has to decide who is to be the Vice-President among the top two candidates. A quorum for this is two-thirds of the Senate, and to make a choice, it needs a majority of all Senators. A person who is not eligible to be President cannot become Vice-President.
